Package squidpony.squidmath

Class SaltyQRNG

java.lang.Object
squidpony.squidmath.SaltyQRNG
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, RandomnessSource, StatefulRandomness
@Beta
public class SaltyQRNG
extends Object
implements StatefulRandomness
A different kind of quasi-random number generator (also called a sub-random sequence) that can be "salted" like some hashing functions can, to produce many distinct sub-random sequences without changing its performance qualities. This generally will be used to produce doubles or floats, using nextDouble() or nextFloat(), and the other generator methods use the same update implementation internally (just without any conversion to floating point). This tends to have fairly good distribution regardless of salt, with the first 16384 doubles produced (between 0.0 and 1.0, for any salt tested) staying separated enough that (int)(result * 32768) will be unique, meaning no two values were closer to each other than they were to their optimally-separated position on a subdivided range of values. That test allows getting "n" unique sub-random values from an integer range with size "n * 2", but if the range is smaller, like if it is just "n" or "n * 3 / 2", this will probably not produce fully unique values. The maximum number of values this can produce without overlapping constantly is 16384, or 2 to the 14. There are 2 different groups of non-overlapping sequences this can produce, with 16384 individual sequences in each group (determined by salt) and each sequence with a period of 16384.
This changed from an earlier version that used exponents of the golden ratio phi, which worked well until it got past 256 values, and then it ceased to be adequately sub-random. The earlier approach also may have had issues with very high exponents being treated as infinite and thus losing any information that could be obtained from them.
Created by Tommy Ettinger on 9/9/2017.
See Also:

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    SaltyQRNG()
    Creates a SaltyQRNG with a random salt and a random starting state.
    SaltyQRNG​(int salt)
    Creates a SaltyQRNG with a specific salt (this should usually be a non-negative int less than 32768).
    SaltyQRNG​(int salt, long advance)
    Creates a SaltyQRNG with a specific salt (this should usually be a non-negative int less than 32768) and a point it has already advanced to in the sequence this generates.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    SaltyQRNG copy()
    Produces a copy of this StatefulRandomness that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called.
    int getSalt()  
    long getState()
    Get the current internal state of the StatefulRandomness as a long.
    int next​(int bits)
    Advances the state twice, causing the same state change as a call to nextInt() or two calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
    double nextDouble()
    Gets the next double in the sequence, between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive)
    float nextFloat()
    Gets the next float in the sequence, between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive)
    int nextInt()
    Advances the state twice, causing the same state change as a call to next(int) or two calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
    long nextLong()
    Advances the state four times, causing the same state change as two calls to nextInt() or next(int), or four calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
    short nextShort()  
    void setSalt​(int newSalt)
    Sets the salt, which should usually be a non-negative int less than 16384, though it can be any int (only the bottom 15 bits are used).
    void setState​(long state)
    Sets the current "state" of the QRNG (which number in the sequence it will produce), using the least-significant 16 bits of a given long.

  • Constructor Details

    • SaltyQRNG

      public SaltyQRNG()
      Creates a SaltyQRNG with a random salt and a random starting state. The random source used here is Math.random(), which produces rather few particularly-random bits, but enough for this step.

    • SaltyQRNG

      public SaltyQRNG​(int salt)
      Creates a SaltyQRNG with a specific salt (this should usually be a non-negative int less than 32768). The salt determines the precise sequence that will be produced over the whole lifetime of the QRNG, and two SaltyQRNG objects with different salt values should produce different sequences, at least at some points in generation. The starting state will be 0, which this tolerates well. The salt is allowed to be 0, since some changes are made to the salt before use.
      Parameters:
      salt - an int; only the bottom 15 bits will be used, so different values range from 0 to 32767

    • SaltyQRNG

      public SaltyQRNG​(int salt, long advance)
      Creates a SaltyQRNG with a specific salt (this should usually be a non-negative int less than 32768) and a point it has already advanced to in the sequence this generates. The salt determines the precise sequence that will be produced over the whole lifetime of the QRNG, and two SaltyQRNG objects with different salt values should produce different sequences, at least at some points in generation. The advance will only have its least-significant 16 bits used, so an int can be safely passed as advance without issue (even a negative int). The salt is allowed to be 0, since some changes are made to the salt before use.
      Parameters:
      salt - an int; only the bottom 15 bits will be used, so different values range from 0 to 32767
      advance - a long to use as the state; only the bottom 32 bits are used, so any int can also be used

  • Method Details

    • getSalt

      public int getSalt()

    • setSalt

      public void setSalt​(int newSalt)
      Sets the salt, which should usually be a non-negative int less than 16384, though it can be any int (only the bottom 15 bits are used). The salt determines the precise sequence that will be produced over the whole lifetime of the QRNG, and two SaltyQRNG objects with different salt values should produce different sequences, at least at some points in generation. The salt is allowed to be 0, since some changes are made to the salt before use.
      Parameters:
      newSalt - an int; only the bottom 15 bits will be used, so different values range from 0 to 32767

    • setState

      public void setState​(long state)
      Sets the current "state" of the QRNG (which number in the sequence it will produce), using the least-significant 16 bits of a given long.
      Specified by:
      setState in interface StatefulRandomness
      Parameters:
      state - a long (0 is tolerated); this only uses the bottom 16 bits, so you could pass a short or an int

    • nextInt

      public int nextInt()
      Advances the state twice, causing the same state change as a call to next(int) or two calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
      Returns:
      a quasi-random int in the full range for ints, which can be negative or positive

    • nextShort

      public short nextShort()

      public int next​(int bits)
      Advances the state twice, causing the same state change as a call to nextInt() or two calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
      Specified by:
      next in interface RandomnessSource
      Parameters:
      bits - an int between 1 and 32, specifying how many quasi-random bits to output
      Returns:
      a quasi-random int that can use up to bits bits

    • nextLong

      public long nextLong()
      Advances the state four times, causing the same state change as two calls to nextInt() or next(int), or four calls to nextFloat() or nextDouble().
      Specified by:
      nextLong in interface RandomnessSource
      Returns:
      a quasi-random long in the full range for longs, which can be negative or positive

      public double nextDouble()

    • copy

      public SaltyQRNG copy()
      Description copied from interface: StatefulRandomness
      Produces a copy of this StatefulRandomness that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
      Specified by:
      copy in interface RandomnessSource
      Specified by:
      copy in interface StatefulRandomness
      Returns:
      a copy of this StatefulRandomness
